prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "reglet and furniture". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Reglet and Furniture

Beware the reglet in the den,
Where couches creak and peep;
Old sofa-rats slouch in the den,
And things that skirr will peep.

He clutched a spindle-rod and chair,
His father left a crumb.
"Take gleam, my boy, and couch-guard near,"
"For chairs do nibble crumbs."

Through woolly lanes the hush was stirred,
Past drawers that clack and creak;
Out slid the reglet, limber-lurled,
It shoomed and shnicked with squeak.

He shouldered couch-guard as a shield,
And brass-chair clung a thrum;
He cried, "Now make its tumbled yield!"
Clang! splick! — the shroom went thrum.

They lugged its flump and rode the road,
On brass-wheels they rode home;
And townsfolk cheered along the road,
While chairs all bowed at home.

And children whispered "reglet, den,"
As couches creak and peep.
So mind the seam that hides the den,
For couches still will peep.
label: high
judge_raw:

<C6_think>Opening line is an admonition "Beware the reglet in the den," clearly an early warning.</C6_think>

<C9_think>Decisive action in stanza 4: "Clang! splick! — the shroom went thrum," onomatopoeia marking a triumphant blow; resolution of tension.</C9_think>
<C10_think>Return and celebration in stanza 5: "rode home," "townsfolk cheered," "chairs all bowed," indicating jubilant homecoming.</C10_think>

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "blued screw in a movement". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Blued Screw in a Movement

Beware the blued-screw's whirling mood,  
it clanks and softly croons.  
It threads the brass of movement's gear,  
and squeal its secret near.

So father gave a clip-clang blade,  
and bade me bind my boots.  
I buckled my sprocket-bound shield,  
and whistled brassy hoots.

We trudged the tick-tuck timber-ways,  
where sproonch and snickle played.  
A glint of blued in geargrass glowed,  
we heard the screw's sirade.

Then sprang the Screwgrin, spindled-fanged,  
it clattered chain and hissed.  
Its blued-bit eyes begoggled brass,  
and tick-tum thumped and hissed.

I bared my glint-gage, snick-snack keen,  
it twynd and opened wide.  
With clack-slashed swing the blued-bit fell,  
and clunk! the movement died.

I hoisted head with sprocket-gore,  
and singed the meadow throngs.  
They cheered my clip and clanking name,  
Beware the blued-screw's move.
label: high

However, exact repeated content words/phrases from opening stanza are less than 2 solid matches. Refrain is partial but not very strong ring composition.</C5_think>

<C7_think>Second stanza shows protagonist preparation: "gave a clip-clang blade," "bade me bind my boots," "buckled my sprocket-bound shield," and "whistled brassy hoots" all show clear preparation and resolve before encounter.</C7_think>
<C8_think>Fourth stanza describes the encounter: "Then sprang the Screwgrin, spindled-fanged," clearly indicating confrontation between protagonist and creature named Screwgrin.</C8_think>

<C10_think>Sixth stanza shows return and celebration: "I hoisted head with sprocket-gore," "They cheered my clip and clanking name," showing triumphant homecoming acknowledgment.</C10_think>

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "murmuration over stubble". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Murmuration Over Stubble

Murmuration o'er the stubble
whush-whirr through harvest hush and field,
Mind Clattawright's clack and rubble,
lest—skree!—it pluck you from your field.

He strapped his glim-gleam to his side,
and cinched his cinder-cloak about;
He paced his skree-song, hush and stride,
and thumbed his knurly map about.

They rose as one, a shadow-bloom,
whirr-swish, the clack of thousand wing;
It pooled, made one—a stubble-plume,
and keened, "skree-skree," a brassy ring.

He sprang with glim-gleam, hiss and strike,
whum! the plume broke swish and flew to smoke;
He cleft its core with glinting spike,
and clack! the feathers rushed to smoke.

He walked, heart-thrum, through husks and stubble,
glim-gleam dulled, the cloak was soot and dim;
They hailed him home through straw and rubble—
Murmuration o'er the stubble.
label: high
judge_raw:
<think>
<C1_think>Title line "Murmuration Over Stubble" before first stanza is present and non-empty.</C1_think>
<C2_think>Poem has 5 stanzas; all are quatrains (4 lines each), stanza count within 5–8 range.</C2_think>
<C3_think>Meter alternation: lines generally vary in length but not clearly with strong content-word count differences alternating line by line in at least 60% of stanzas; some stanzas show mixed line lengths but no clear long/short alternation pattern as in classic ballad meter.</C3_think>
<C4_think>Rhyme scheme: (2,4) lines mostly rhyme or slant rhyme in at least 3 of 5 stanzas, and no obvious AABB dominance; rhyme is consistent but subtle.</C4_think>
<C5_think>Final stanza echoes the opening stanza with exact or near-exact repeated phrases "Murmuration o'er the stubble" and "stubble" repeated; at least two repeated content words or clear refrain present.</C5_think>
<C6_think>Early admonition: stanza 1 includes a caution "Mind Clattawright's clack and rubble, lest—skree!—it pluck you"; functions as a warning.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Preparation: stanza 2 shows protagonist preparing with "strapped his glim-gleam," "cinched his cinder-cloak," "paced his skree-song," "thumbed his knurly map"; clear preparation act before encounter.</C7_think>
<C8_think>Encounter: stanza 3 and 4 describe the rising murmurating entity and the confrontation ("He sprang with glim-gleam, hiss and strike"); clear meeting and conflict.</C8_think>
<C9_think>Slaying/decisive action: stanza 4 includes "He cleft its core with glinting spike," a fatal act ending the tension.</C9_think>
<C10_think>Return/celebration: stanza 5 depicts return "He walked, heart-thrum," and being hailed home; joyful acknowledgment implied.</C10_think>
<C11_think>Counted coinages: glim-gleam, cinder-cloak, skree, clattawright, knurly, skree-song, swish, whum, clack (some onomatopoeic repeated as coinages); at least 8 distinct invented coinages present.</C11_think>
<C12_think>Every stanza contains at least one coinage: e.g., first (clattawright, skree), second (glim-gleam, cinder-cloak, skree-song, knurly), third (whirr-swish, clack, skree-skree), fourth (glim-gleam, whum, clack), fifth (glim-gleam, rubble).</C12_think>
<C13_think>Creature/entity named and central: "Murmuration" is an entity of birds, but here "Clattawright" seems the named foe/protagonist's concern; it appears as a non-canonical creature/entity central to action.</C13_think>
<C14_think>Onomatopoeia present: "whush-whirr," "skree," "whirr-swish," "whum," "clack," several burst sounds used prominently.</C14_think>
<C15_think>Alliteration/consonance clearly present in ≥2 stanzas, e.g., stanza 1 "clack and rubble," stanza 2 "cinched his cinder-cloak," stanza 3 "shadow-bloom," "whirr-swish, the clack," and stanza 5 "heart-thrum, husks and stubble."</C15_think>

<C18_think>Canonical tokens (e.g., jabberwock, vorpal, tulgey, snicker-snack) are absent; no canonical words appear; so canonical token count <=8 is satisfied.</C18_think>
<C19_think>Syllable counts approximate ballad meter: longer lines mostly 8-9 syllables, shorter lines about 5-7 syllables; consistent with Jabberwocky pattern in all quatrains.</C19_think>
<C20_think>Rhyme in (2,4) lines varied; end words not overused more than twice (excluding ring echo); rhyme endings differ across stanzas with no obvious repetition.</C20_think>
<C21_think>No content word is repeated excessively (>5 times or >8%); lexical repetition is moderate and controlled.</C21_think>
<C22_think>Coinages show variety in roots: "glim," "gleam," "cinder," "cloak," "skree," "clack," "knurly," "whum," "swish"; no single suffix or root dominates >50% coinages.</C22_think>
<C23_think>Topic adherence: poem clearly treats a mythical creature hunting encounter, matching the given Jabberwocky style and motif without changing subject.</C23_think>
